pros: Wonderful people and great community
cons: Relatively small organization can lead to lack of advancement opportunity

review_title: Seriously clueless organization. how are they are still operating?
pros: VERY generous with time off. No one wants to work - Fridays off in the summer, 4 weeks off for vacation. A week, or more, off in winter break. Personal days. Bereavement day, Sick days. Every single state and federal holiday.
cons: Very poorly run and managed. The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing. Yet, look at the federal tax filings. Senior management makes $$$. For example, the head of advancement earns about $250K annually. But what does she do to earn that? The school is drawing down their endowment (which was already not very high), and enrollment is down. They are not keeping pace with trends in higher education. The only trend they seem to be interested in is woke ideology.

pros: The only pro is the people, other than senior management
cons: School is tanking, layoffs coming. Poor to no communication from senior management.

pros: Great community who are dedicated to serving students
cons: Some staff are toxic and affect the work environment and success f the institution

pros:
-Learn a lot about the inner workings of a university
-Lots of flexibility
-Learn about software such as Salesforce
cons:
-Few hours available
-Not always a lot to do

job_title: Senior Assistant Director of Admissions in Auburndale, MA
pros: Benefits are amazing. Work life balance is great.
cons: Salary isnt the best. But better than other schools

pros: Loved working there, great staff
cons: Limited hours, hard to schedule

pros:
Nice campus great location 
Some motivated students
cons: Management should be more inclusive

job_title: Assistant Director of Graduate Student Services in Newton, MA
pros: Transparency from President all the way down to the student body; people love their jobs
cons: No cons that I can speak to

pros:
good pay 
good hours
fun people
cons:
small facilities 
limited class sizes

pros: I generally felt fairly supported by fellow faculty, and I enjoyed the students
cons: It's an adjunct job. At the very least you are financially undervalued with no benefits and just over $3000 per course per semester. The entire adjunct system is deeply inequitable throughout this country. Change of department management can quickly change the environment and valuation of adjuncts

pros: There's a high level of autonomy in writing your syllabus and planning what you're going to teach in whichever classes you've been assigned. There are two or three students per semester who are really engaged.
cons: The pay is a pittance. If you don't have a full roster of students (through no fault of your own) they'll try to cut your pay claiming that the money offered you was for a "full" course load of at least 18 students. Adjuncts get mostly intro courses, and students don't care about them (they're generally requirements). The flip side of the autonomy is that there is ZERO feedback from department heads. Many of the other professors I dealt with were not interested in helping adjuncts. Students gripe about their grades after doing the absolute bare minimum work required.

pros: The closest pro I can come up with is that it is better than unemployment. It's not somewhere I'd suggest working long term. But if you need some quick job experience, then it is doable while you find somewhere better to work.
cons:
Horrible pay. Generally only get offered a bunch of introductory courses. They can be fine, but teaching multiple every semester is tiring and not stimulating. Students don't care and don't want to do any work. Students show up to class late, don't read, don't want to do any assignments. This is typical anywhere for a few students, but when it's almost all it is discouraging. I'd rather teach at community college for similar pay with students who are at least working hard to not be poor.

I teach at another university in the area and my experience there is the complete opposite. If it weren't for knowing that it could be better, Lasell would have probably turned me off academia completely.

review_title: Excellent work place for growth and understanding
pros: Lasell is a great liberal arts school that allows and encourages for staff and faculty to continue profession pursuits, professional development, and further both the educational platform in which they teach and the student's understanding of the world
cons: The only con I see as a professor is the lack of performing arts based degrees for students who wish to have a more specific minor/second major in a particular art form

review_title: Don’t believe a word they say!
pros: Nice faculty members, some rewarding students to work with
cons: Inequitable, unkind, shady, privileged, senior managers; pay lip service to social justice and it is taught but not practiced by management; appalling pay inequality; secret deals while lying to students & employees; HR does nothing to address problems, only refers people to EAP; zero consequences for bad actors; school’s money goes to window dressing for prospective students, not to academics or pay equality; faculty/staff consistently undermined & input ignored; students not graduating with research or professional skills & say high school was more difficult

review_title: Lasell College has allowed provided me with a great opportunity to build and expand my academic career.
pros:
Collaborative atmosphere as faculty across all departments are helpful. 
Lasell allows part-time faculty the same opportunities and respect as full-time professors. 
Small class sizes allow for faculty to engage in the material, build relationships with students and access individual learning needs/styles. 
Very supportive department chair.
cons:
Part-time salary is not as competitive as other neighboring colleges in New-England.
Lack of consistent communication between student advisor and faculty. 
Graduate programs shifting to online and hybrid formats which hinders students from developing their face-to-face skills.

pros:
- Great students, very passionate about their field of study
- Lots of opportunity for collaboration with great colleagues; everyone knows each other
- President Alexander is a fantastic leader who knows almost all staff and makes an effort to meet every student - very student centered.
cons:
- Student Affairs leaders/division are not open to change
- Low compensation
- Few opportunities for advancement. Lots of entry level and upper management positions; few middle management.

pros: Working at a Resident Assistant at Lasell was a very fulfilling experience. The full time staff was always there to support me and other members of the staff. Lasell is a fantastic community to be a part of.
cons: It's difficult to think that hard of a downside to working at Lasell, but if I were to pick one in my role as a Resident Assistant the pay was not great.

job_title: Technology HelpDesk Coordinator in Auburndale, MA
pros: Such a great small group of people that take the time to get to know students and other employees. Very close-knight and easy to join the team. Everyone helps one another.
cons: Some clients can be rude and impatient, but that's the same as anywhere

review_title: Great place to work for somebody with a family!
pros: College culture, low stress, great colleagues, very respectful students. Good benefits both for faculty and staff.
cons: Teaching rooms need some updates, some of the faculty needs to retire, administration needs to be less bureaucratic (I know, right?)

review_title: Nice place to be employed,I truly enjoy it.
pros:
Nice people, free college classes for employees, free tuition for children, after 1 year of service.
I have summers off and 1 month off inbetween semesters.
cons: poor parking situtation, too many VP's, salary not the best, competitive but raises are very small.

pros: Great co-workers, always events to go to, active campus, always growing, good benefits, nice management
cons: Can't think of any

pros: Very flexible work environment. Can take leaves at a short notice. options for telecommute. Senior management very approachable.
cons: There is no clear direction for growth potential.

review_title: Great, small college just outside Boston
pros: Lasell has a great location, just outside of Boston - easy to get to from many areas of New England
cons: Depending on what division you work in, there are little opportunities for growth/promotion

pros: Lasell College Alumni Relations is a great work environment. I began my job there as an assistant . I got promoted after the first month.
cons: I don't think there are any cons.

review_title: It was a great place to teach
pros: If you want to teach aerobics the students got very excited about it
cons: Enough students to teach to

pros: Love the school, great on campus job opportunities and ways to get involved. Very strong sense of community.
cons: Can feel isolating at times.

pros: Great people, excellent work environment
cons: I really enjoyed my time here. Not too many bad things to say

-Great exposure
cons: -No compensation for events [because I am a student]

cons: Parking is a little difficult at times
